con.para: Quantum physics explains how the tiniest particles in the universe work. Unlike regular physics, things in the quantum world don’t follow the usual rules!
In the quantum world, particles behave in strange ways. Sometimes they act like particles, sometimes like waves! This is why quantum physics is so different.
Light can be both a particle and a wave at the same time! This is called the particle-wave duality. It’s why light can shine through glass (like a wave) but can also push objects (like a particle).
Relativity, discovered by Albert Einstein, explains how time and space are connected. It helps us understand how things move at really high speeds, close to the speed of light.
Special relativity says that time moves slower for something moving really fast. This is called time dilation. Astronauts traveling close to the speed of light would age more slowly!
Length contraction happens when objects moving at high speeds appear shorter to someone watching. If a spaceship zooms past, it will look shorter than it really is!

con.title: General Relativity: Gravity as Spacetime Curvature

con.para: General relativity says that gravity isn’t just a force—it’s the bending of space and time. Large objects like Earth or the Sun bend spacetime, and that’s why things fall towards them.
Atoms are made up of even smaller particles, like electrons, neutrinos, and quarks. These tiny particles are the building blocks of everything!
Electrons orbit the nucleus of an atom. Neutrinos are tiny, nearly invisible particles that rarely interact with anything. Quarks combine to form protons and neutrons.

con.title: The Standard Model of Particle Physics

con.para: The Standard Model explains all the particles that make up the universe, like electrons, quarks, and neutrinos. It’s like a recipe book for the universe!
Modern physics helps us understand things like how the universe started, how stars shine, and how technology like computers and GPS work!
